title: Adopt and Manage application
content:
Adopt and Manage (AnM) is a custom Studio application that can be used to onboard virtual machines (VMs) that are hosted on private or public cloud providers into Cloud Management. These VMs can then be used as part of Cloud Management to create service catalogs and offerings. The AnM application supports Microsoft Azure, AWS, and VMware vCenter providers. This document explains how to import this application into Cloud Management and use it to adopt and manage the compute resources from the supported providers.

Personas

User Responsibilities
Cloud Management user Tenant admin role
Subscription owner Service portal user role

Roles

User Responsibilities
Tenant admin Configure the resource provider
Service portal user View and execute actions on the subscription

Prerequisites

Download the following capsules from ITOM Marketplace:

  • Microsoft Azure Capsule (CloudSlang)
  • Amazon AWS Capsule (CloudSlang)
  • VMWare vCenter Capsule (CloudSlang)

Download the following content packs from ITOM Marketplace:

  • OO Amazon AWS Content Pack
  • OO Microsoft Azure Content Pack (CloudSlang)
  • OO VMware vCenter Content Pack (CloudSlang)

Create an Azure resource provider

Follow these steps to create an Azure resource provider:

  1. Log in to the Agent Interface as a tenant admin.
  2. Go to Administration > Utilities > Providers > Deployment Resource Providers.
  3. Select the provider type from the panel on the left.
  4. Select the gear icon at the top right of the toolbar.
  5. Select Create Resource Provider.
  6. The Create Resource Provider window opens.
  7. Enter the Display Name.
  8. Enter the Service Access Point.
  9. Enter the User ID and Password in the respective fields.
  10. Select Create.

The Cloud Management platform creates the following provider:

  • Provider: MICROSOFT_AZURE
  • Provider type: Microsoft Azure
  • Service access point: https://management.azure.com/

Create an Amazon resource provider

Follow these steps to create an Amazon resource provider:

  1. Log in to the Agent Interface as an administrator.
  2. Go to Administration > Utilities > Providers > Deployment Resource Providers.
  3. Select the provider type from the panel on the left.
  4. Select the Gear icon   at the top right of the toolbar.
  5. Select Create Resource Provider.
  6. The Create Resource Provider window opens.
  7. Enter the Display Name.
  8. Enter the Service Access Point.
  9. Enter the Access Key ID and Secret Access Key in the respective fields.
  10. Select Create.

The Cloud Management platform creates the following provider:

  • Provider name: AMAZON_EC2
  • Provider type: Amazon AWS
  • Service access point: https://ec2.amazonaws.com:443

Configure AWS Command line interface (CLI)

To get the values for the AWS CSV file, you need to:

  1. Download and install the AWS CLI.
  2. Configure the AWS account by running this command:
    aws configure
  3. Provide the following values:
AWS Access Key ID:
AWS Secret Access Key:
Default region name:
Default output format:

Now the AWS CLI is ready for you to run the commands mentioned in Export the compute resources section.

Create a VMware vCenter resource provider

To create a VMware vCenter resource provider in the Cloud Management environment, follow these steps:

  1. Log in to the Agent Interface as an administrator.
  2. Go to Administration > Utilities > Providers > Deployment Resource Providers.
  3. Select the provider type from the panel on the left.
  4. Select the Gear icon   at the top right of the toolbar.
  5. Select Create Resource Provider.
  6. On the Create Resource Provider window, enter the Display Name, Service Access Point, User ID, and Password.
  7. Select Create.

The Cloud Management platform creates the following provider:

  • Provider name: VMWARE_VCENTER
  • Provider type: VMware vCenter
  • Service access point: https://<vCenter-Server>:443

Configure VMware PowerCLI

To get the values for the AWS CSV file, you need to:

  1. Download and install the VMware PowerCLI.
  2. Configure VMware vCenter Account by running this command: 
    Connect-VIServer -Server <server> -User <user> -Password <password>

Now the VMware PowerCLI is ready for you to run the commands mentioned in the "Export the compute resources" section.

Download the AnM package

Download the AnM package appropriate for the current release from the ITOM Marketplace. Note that the package version is in a Major.Minor.MinorMinor format:

  • Major updates occur rarely and involve breaking compatibility with earlier releases, such as discontinued support or a change in the API.
  • Minor updates introduce new functionality, such as adding properties to component templates or OO flows, and new features.
  • Minor.Minor updates involve minimal changes, such as updating descriptions without affecting functionality.

To download the appropriate AnM package:

  1. Visit the Adopt and Manage page on the ITOM Marketplace, download the appropriate Adopt-and-Manage-<version>.zip file, and save it to a temp folder.
  2. Extract the Adopt-and-Manage-<version>.zip file.
  3. From the Adopt-and-Manage-<version> directory, select and extract the CloudSlang Adopt and Manage Package.zip file.
  4. Double-click service-designs to open the directory. The extracted service-designs directory contains packages (in one .zip file) and service designs (in three .zip files) for Amazon AWS, Microsoft Azure, and VMware vCenter Compute.
  5. Extract the Adopt_and_Manage_studio_app_packages.zip file. The extracted Adopt_and_Manage_studio_app_packages directory contains the AnM and integration packages (.pkb files).

The following table shows the components that are required for installation.

Component Description
AnM package

The AnM package comprises a .pkb file that includes the Studio application, the provider entities, and the service catalogs and service offerings.

You will find two .pkb AnM package files under the \Adopt-and-Manage-<version>\CloudSlang Adopt and Manage Package\service-designs\Adopt_and_Manage_studio_app_packages directory. Choose the package depending on your Cloud Management environment.

  • Package-Adopt and Manage Studio App_25.4.pkb supports Cloud Management 25.4

  • Package-Adopt and Manage Studio App_24.2.pkb and_24.4.pkb supports Cloud Management 24.2 and 24.4 

  • Package-Adopt and Manage Studio App_23.4.pkb and_24.1.pkb supports Cloud Management 23.4 and 24.1

  • Package-Adopt and Manage Studio App_24.3.pkb supports Cloud Management 24.3
The integration package You will find three .pkb integration package files under the \Adopt-and-Manage-<version>\CloudSlang Adopt and Manage Package\service-designs\Adopt_and_Manage_studio_app_packages directory. Choose the package depending on your Cloud Management environment.
  • integration_package_25.4.pkb supports Cloud Management 25.4
  • integration_package_24.2.pkb supports Cloud Management 24.2
  • integration_package_24.1.pkb supports Cloud Management 24.1
  • integration_package_23.4.pkb supports Cloud Management 23.4
  • integration_package_24.3pkb supports Cloud Management 24.3
  • integration_package_24.4.pkb supports Cloud Management 24.4
CSC Resource Onboarding (CloudSlang) <version> content pack The CSC Resource Onboarding (CloudSlang) <version> content pack (\Adopt-and-Manage-<version>\csc-resource-onboarding-cp-<version> file) includes onboarding workflows for Azure, AWS, and VMware vCenter providers.

Amazon AWS Compute Instance Onboarding (CloudSlang) - AnM Onboarding <version>

 This is the service design for an AWS provider.

Microsoft Azure Compute Advanced (CloudSlang) - AnM Onboarding <version>

 This is the service design for an Azure provider.

VMware vCenter Compute - Deploy VM from Template (CloudSlang) - AnM Onboarding <version>

 This is the service design for a VMware vCenter provider.

Import the content pack for the provider

You can deploy the content packs in OO Central after downloading the content pack from ITOM Marketplace.

  1. Log in to the agent portal.
  2. From the main menu, go to Run > Automation Operations.
  3. Selecting Automation Operations will open the Operations Orchestration (OO) Central.
  4. Click the Content Management button to display the Content Management workspace.
  5. Under the Content Packs tab, click the Deploy New Content button.
  6. In the Deploy New Content dialog box, click the Add button.
  7. Browse and select CSC Resource Onboarding (CloudSlang) <version> content pack and then click Open. 
  8. Click Deploy.

Import the service design for the provider

You can import the service design from the Service Designer.

Log in to the agent portal and from the main menu, select Build > Design to go to Service Designer. 

  1. Click the gear icon to select Import Design action.
  2. Go to the \Adopt-and-Manage-<version>\CloudSlang Adopt and Manage Package\service-designs directory and select the respective service design .zip file to import.
  3. Click Import.

Import the AnM package

To import the .pkb file, follow these steps:

  1. Log in to the Agent Interface as a tenant admin.
  2. After downloading the .pkb file to your local system, go to Administration > Utilities > Packages.

In the OPTIONS tab, select Import a package and import the required package.

Run a simulation import: 

Click SIMULATE, browse to the package bundle file, and click Open. The simulation automatically starts. Wait for the simulation to complete without error. If any issues, fix them and then rerun the simulation import

Import a Service Catalog package:

  1. Click IMPORT, and browse to the package bundle (.pkb) file to import it. A window opens and displays the progress and statistics of the package import process (the process may take a long time).

  2. Go to Plan > Service Catalog > Catalog > Adopt and Manage > Adopt and Manage Service Definition, and then update the service offerings on the right-side pane with the resource provider name.

After the import, you can use Studio to view the fields, forms, processes, and business rules added for the AnM application. The following figure shows the imported fields. 

Import the Integration package

This includes the scenario for all providers.

  1. Log in to the agent portal and from the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.
  2. Click the gear icon in the left pane, and then click Import.
  3. In the Import dialog, click Select, select the export file, and then click Open.
  4. Click Upload.
  5. Wait until the import Status changes to one of the final statuses (Success, Completed with errors, Failed), and then click OK. If succeeded or completed with errors, review the summary of the import in the Detail grid. For failed items, click the hyperlinked number in the Failed column to view the error message.

Create the endpoint and add it to the Integration Scenario

Log in to the agent portal, and from the main menu, select Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.

Create an endpoint of type Rest Executor 2.0. Configure the endpoint with Agentless and Generic Authentication Type. You do not need the OPB Agent for REST Executor 2.0 endpoint.

Configure the Cloud Management Instance URL as the endpoint for the integration scenario to connect and execute the onboarding scenario.

Field Value
General Configuration section

Agent

Select Agentless (if not using the OPB Agent) or the OPB agent created for the endpoint.
Authentication type Select Generic.
Protocol Select https.
Base URL Enter the base URL of the target system: https://<FQDN>

Authentication URL

Enter the authentication URL of the IDM Service: https://<FQDN>/idm-service/v3.0/tokens

Certificate type

 Select X.509.

Certificate format

 Select PEM.

Server certificate

Open the root CA certificate file of the Cloud Management Instance in a text editor, and then copy and paste the content to this field. If the content is invalid, an error occurs when you click Save in the next step. 

The certificate content must resemble the following.

-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIF2TCCBMGgAwIBAgIQBMF1U8hY8bivE0+JHx922jANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQsFADBG
MQswCQYDVQQGEwJVUzEPMA0GA1UEChMGQW1hem9uMRUwEwYDVQQLEwxTZXJ2ZXIg
Q0EgMUIxDzANBgNVBAMTBkFtYXpvbjAeFw0yMTEwMTEwMDAwMDBaFw0yMjExMDky
MzU5NTlaMBsxGTAXBgNVBAMTEHhpZS5pdHNtYS1uZy5vcmcwggEiMA0GCSqGSIb3
1oIvQfpl2gj0S6JSJAYjJnY7HKCa7mkzBMiiXWI5aHMZfl1FsaNARM10LUpto61f
Ivk/SDNlOqVXuzGMTZkJBVZVmK5lNLvBB1Gk9+QlJ+SuUOW7FW2K5U+oQKWsHtvH
C/DHn6yyhvqWes9q6A==
-----END CERTIFICATE-----

Configure authentication request section

Construct headers and body for requests sent to the IDM authentication. After entering the request headers and body, click Test connection to validate the configuration.
Encrypted data

Click +Add, enter the password in the Parameter field, and key in the password of the API integration user used to interact with the APIs.
Header

Add the following two headers

Content-Type: application/json

Accept: application/json
Body

Enter the IDM authentication request

{
    "passwordCredentials": {
        "username": "<integration user>",
        "password": "${password}"
    },
    "tenantName": "<tenant-id>"
}

Extract data from authentication response section

Extract properties from various parts of the authentication response so that the properties can be used in subsequent requests. To extract a property, click +Add, and then specify values for the following fields.
Parameter

XAuthToken 
HTTP element Body
Expression $.token.id

Configure headers and cookies for subsequent requests section

Construct headers and cookies for requests that are sent after the IDM authentication process is completed by clicking +Add. Add the following entries, this includes all the headers required for different ESM and EMS APIs that are using the scenario.

Key HTTP Element Expression
Authorization Header Bearer ${XAuthToken}
SMAX_AUTH_TOKEN Cookie SMAX_AUTH_TOKEN=${XAuthToken}
TENANTID Header <tenant-id>
TENANTID Cookie <tenant-id>
X-Auth-Token Header ${XAuthToken}

After testing the endpoint, configure the endpoint in the AnM Onboarding Integration.

  1. Open the AnM Onboarding integration from Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.
  2. Under Connector-Enpoint mappings, select the endpoint created from the above step in the Endpoint.
  3. Configure the Current system integration user, and enter the user credentials with permission to create a subscription on behalf of the onboarding users.
  4. Update the TENANTID, OFFERINGID, and hcmxUser in the Initialize HCMX data step of all three scenarios. 
    For the hcmxUser parameter, you can specify the UPN of a user who has permission to request on behalf of the subscription owners. To do this, you can add the subscription owners or their groups to the "Request on behalf" tab of hcmxUser. The following figure shows an example. 

Once all the packages are imported, then you need to export the data from your cloud provider which you need to onboard into Cloud Management. Follow the provider-specific topics on how to do this.

Export the compute resources

AWS

Use the aws describe commands to extract the data into the CSV file. The following are the CSV headers that you need to add to the CSV file:

CloudInstanceID_c,InstanceName_c,InstanceType_c,AMIID_c,KeyPair_c,Region_c,AvailabilityZone_c,PrivateIPAddress_c,PrivateDNSName_c,PublicIPAddress_c,PublicDNSName_c,VPCID_c,SubnetID_c,MACAddress_c,PlatformType_c,InstanceState_c,SecurityGroupIDList_c,OfferingId_c,SubscriptionOwner_c,AWSResourceType_c,OnboardingStatus_c

Command to get the AWS compute resource;

aws ec2 describe-instances --output text --query "Reservations[*].Instances[*].[InstanceId, [Tags[?Key==`Name`].Value] [0][0], InstanceType, ImageId, KeyPair, Placement.AvailabilityZone, Placement.AvailabilityZone, Placement, PrivateIPAddress, PrivateDNSName, PublicIPAddress, PublicDNSName, VPCID, SubnetID, NetworkInterfaces[0].MACAddress, PlatformDetails, State.Name, SecurityGroups[*].GroupID ]"

Please note, this will be region specific and you would need to execute it with different regions

To filter a specific instance, use the --instance-ids filter; like the following 

aws ec2 describe-instances --output text --query "Reservations[*].Instances[*].[InstanceId, [Tags[?Key==`Name`].Value] [0][0], InstanceType, ImageID, KeyPair, Placement.AvailabilityZone, Placement.AvailabilityZone, PrivateIPAddress, PrivateDNSName, PublicIPAddress, PublicDNSName, VPCID, SubnetID, NetworkInterfaces[0].MACAddress, PlatformDetails, State.Name, SecurityGroups[*].GroupID ]" --instance-ids i-0c855d63f172f8606

Azure

  1. Log into the Azure Portal. 
  2. Go to Home > All resources.
  3. Select Open query.
  4. Enter the following query to get the Azure VM resources: 
    Resources
| where type =~ 'microsoft.compute/virtualmachines'
| project id, CloudInstanceID=tolower(tostring(id)), InstanceName=name, InstanceType=properties.hardwareProfile.vmSize, resourceGroup, location,
    OSType=properties.storageProfile.osDisk.osType, OSImage=strcat(properties.storageProfile.imageReference.offer,"#",properties.storageProfile.imageReference.publisher,
    "#",properties.storageProfile.imageReference.sku,"#",properties.storageProfile.imageReference.version,"#False"),
    PowerState=properties.extended.instanceView.powerState.displayStatus,StorageType=properties.storageProfile.osDisk.managedDisk.storageAccountType,
    DiskName=properties.storageProfile.osDisk.name, DiskSize=properties.storageProfile.osDisk.diskSizeGB, VMID=properties.vmId,VMUsername=properties.osProfile.adminUsername, tags
| join (Resources
    | where type =~ 'microsoft.network/networkinterfaces'
    | mv-expand ipconfig=properties.ipConfigurations
    | project CloudInstanceID = tolower(tostring(properties.virtualMachine.id)), privateIp=ipconfig.properties.privateIPAddress, publicIpId=tostring(ipconfig.properties.publicIPAddress.id), 
          subnetId=tostring(ipconfig.properties.subnet.id), vmNICId=tostring(ipconfig.properties.publicIPAddress.properties.ipConfiguration.id), macAddress=tostring(properties.macAddress),
          privateDNSSuffix=tostring(properties.dnsSettings.internalDomainNameSuffix)
    | parse kind=regex subnetId with '/virtualNetworks/' virtualNetwork '/subnets/' subnet
    | parse kind=regex vmNICId with '/networkInterfaces/' nicName '/ipConfigurations/' ipConfigName
    | parse kind=regex CloudInstanceID with '/virtualmachines/' instanceName
    | join kind=leftouter (Resources
        | where type =~ 'microsoft.network/publicipaddresses'
        | project publicIpId = id, publicIp = properties.ipAddress, PrimaryDNSName=properties.dnsSettings.fqdn, PublicIPAddressName=properties.dnsSettings.domainNameLabel
    ) on publicIpId
    | join kind=leftouter (Resources
        | where type =~ 'microsoft.network/virtualnetworks'
        | mv-expand subnet = properties.subnets
        | project subnetId = tostring(subnet.id), subnetName=tostring(subnet.name), subnetCIDR=subnet.properties.addressPrefix
    ) on subnetId
    | project-away publicIpId1
    | summarize privateIps = make_list(privateIp), publicIps = make_list(publicIp), PrimaryDNSNames = make_list(PrimaryDNSName),PublicIPAddressNames = make_list(PublicIPAddressName) by CloudInstanceID,
      subnetId, subnetName, virtualNetwork, nicName, macAddress, PrivateDNSName=strcat(instanceName,".",privateDNSSuffix)
  ) on CloudInstanceID
| project-away id, CloudInstanceID1,subnetId
| sort by InstanceName asc
  5. The following are the CSV headers that you need to use and populate: 
CloudInstanceID_c,InstanceName_c,InstanceType_c,ResourceGroup_c,AvailabilityOptions_c,InfrastructureOptions_c,Location_c,OSType_c,OSImage_c,PowerState_c,PrivateDNSName_c,PrivateIPAddress_c,VirtualNetwork_c,MACAddress_c,NICName_c,EnablePublicIP_c,PrimaryDNSName_c,PublicIPAddresses_c,PublicIPAddressName_c,StorageType_c,DiskName_c,DiskSize_c,SubnetName_c,VMID_c,VMPassword_c,VMUsername_c,OnboardingStatus_c,OnboardingSubscriptionID_c,OfferingID_c,SubscriptionOwner_c,OnboardingStatus_c
  • Manually enter the values for OfferingId_c, SubscriptionOwner_c, AzureResourceType_c, OnboardingStatus_c in the .csv file.

VMWare

Use the VMWare PowerCLI command to get the resources from the VMware vCenter. The following are the CSV headers which you need to use and populate:

VMID_c,VMName_c,HostName_c,IPAddress_c,CPU_c,CustomizationSpecName_c,Datacenter_c,Datastore_c,DiskSize_c,DomainName_c,MACAddress_c,Memory_c,VMFolder_c,VMGuestOS_c,VMTemplateName_c,OfferingID_c,SubscriptionOwner_c

Command to get the VMware VMs:

Connect-VIServer -Server <server> -User <user> -Password <password>

Get-VM | Select Id,Name,VMHost,@{N="IP Address";E={@($_.guest.IPAddress -join '|')}},@{N='FQDN';E={$_.ExtensionData.Guest.IPStack[0].DnsConfig.HostName,$_.ExtensionData.Guest.IPStack[0].DnsConfig.DomainName -join '.'}},PowerState,NumCpu,MemoryGB,ProvisionedSpaceGB,Uid</password></user></server>


Onboard the compute resources

After you export data, you can import them into the corresponding studio app. Ensure the CSV file columns are adjusted based on the studio app fields for the import: you have set the SubscriptionOwner_c with the user to whom the subscription will be created and OfferingId_c with the Onboarding Offering ID.

  1. Log in to the agent portal and from the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio.

  2. Select the required record type and click the Import Data tab.

  3. Click on Browse and select the CSV file to import.

  4. Click Import.

Once you have the data imported, you can verify them in the Adopt and Manage section and select the provider-specific tabs. By default, the OnboardingStatus of all the records is set to NEW. The OnboardingStatus column needs to be set to NEED_TO_ONBOARD for the records to be imported. You can test the import by marking one of the records as NEED_TO_ONBOARD and the rest of them as NEW.

Select the Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio. Select the AnM Onboarding and click on the required provider-specific onboarding scenario. In the Initialize HCMX data section, set the scenario values as per your environment - TENANTID, OFFERINGID, StartDate, EndDate, and hcmxUser.

Execute the corresponding integration scenario to onboard the compute resources into Cloud Management. Verify the subscription is created from Instance Management, the AnM record property is updated with the Onboarding Service Request ID and the Onboarding Status is marked ON_BOARDED. You can log in to the Service Portal as the Subscription Owner and perform the user operations as well as modify the subscription if this option is available to ensure everything is working.

After you have tested enough, you can onboard all the remaining resources by setting them to NEED_TO_ONBOARD.

Create schedulers to run the scenarios

Create a scheduler for each imported scenario. For details, see Scheduler. 

Troubleshoot

You might find the below warnings. You can use the below steps to take action.

Warning Action
Failed to get the entity link value : Field Name:'OwnedByPerson'; Field entity link type: 'Person'; Field values: [{Field='Upn', Value=admin}] After importing the offerings, update the Owner field with the valid user in the Default values section.
Failed to validate the enumeration: enumeration value [2c9083xxxx] for the enumeration name [DynamicListxxxx_c] does not exist. Update the Resource Provider field in the User Options under the AnM Onboarding in the Default values section.
Offering-xxxx(source)Record UUID: [xxxx-xxxx] contains the following errors: Failed to get the entity link value : Field Name: 'CostCenter'; Field entity link type: 'CostCenter'; Field values: [{Field='Code', Value=ProviderCC}]; If you are using the expense lines, then update the Cost Type and Cost Center accordingly. Otherwise, ignore this warning.
